Title:
Workload-Aware Systems and Interfaces for Cognitive Augmentation Dissertation an der Fakultät für Mathematik, Informatik und Statistik der Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München vorgelegt von Thomas-Andreas Kosch M. Sc. Software Engineering München, den 28. Januar 2020 arXiv: 2010. 07703v2 cs. HC 21 Oct 2020 Erstgutachter: Prof. Dr. Albrecht Schmidt Zweitgutachter: Prof. Dr. Fabio Paternò Drittgutachter: Prof. Dr. Jonathan Lazar Tag der mündlichen Prüfung: 11. 05. 2020 iv Abstract Abstract In todays society, our cognition is constantly inﬂuenced by information intake, attention switching, and task interruptions. This increases the diﬃculty of a given task, adding to the existing workload and leading to compromised cognitive performances. The human body expresses the use of cognitive resources through physiological responses when confronted with a plethora of cognitive workload.

Main Topic:
This paper focuses on 11. 05. 2020 iv Abstract Abstract In todays society, our cognition is constantly inﬂuenced by information intake, attention switching, and task interruptions. This increases the diﬃculty of a given task, adding to the existing workload and leading to compromised cognitive performances. The human body expresses the use of cognitive resources through physiological responses when confronted with a plethora of cognitive workload..

Abstract Summary:
This temporarily mobilizes additional resources to deal with the workload at the cost of accelerated mental exhaustion. Firstly, we show that electroencephalography is a reliable modality to assess the mental workload generated during the user interface operation.

Key Points:
1. This temporarily mobilizes additional resources to deal with the workload at the cost of accelerated mental exhaustion.
2. We predict that recent developments in physiological sensing will increasingly create user interfaces that are aware of the users cognitive capacities, hence able to intervene when high or low states of cognitive workload are detected.
3. In this thesis, we initially focus on determining opportune moments for cognitive assistance.
